effective_dosage: Not specified (diets provided 15% or 38% of energy from fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-monounsaturated-fat diet versus a high-carbohydrate diet on lipoprotein profiles in individuals with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The high-monounsaturated-fat diet showed favorable effects on fasting lipoprotein profiles, including lower LDL cholesterol, plasma total triglycerides, and VLDL triglycerides, as well as higher apolipoprotein A1 and longer LDL oxidation lag time in adherent participants. However, results were mixed in the intent-to-treat group, with only LDL cholesterol showing a significant reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 1 diabetes (n=26, with 7 fully adherent to both diets).
effective_dosage: 17% to 20% of total daily calories from monounsaturated fat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of substituting walnuts for part of the monounsaturated fat in a cholesterol-lowering Mediterranean diet on serum lipid levels and LDL oxidizability in hypercholesterolemic individuals.
results_summary: The walnut diet significantly reduced total cholesterol (-4.1%), LDL cholesterol (-5.9%), and lipoprotein(a) levels (-6.2%) compared to the Mediterranean diet, with preserved LDL resistance to oxidation. Lipid changes were similar in men and women, except for lipoprotein(a), which decreased only in men.
population_specificity: 55 men and women (mean age 56) with polygenic hypercholesterolemia.
effective_dosage: Walnuts replaced approximately 35% of the energy obtained from monounsaturated fat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a monounsaturated fat-rich diet (MUFA) with other dietary regimens (saturated fat and NCEP-I) on carbohydrate metabolism and blood pressure in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The MUFA diet resulted in the lowest fasting blood glucose, insulin, and free fatty acid levels compared to the NCEP-I diet, and lower blood pressure than the NCEP-I diet. The saturated fat diet induced higher insulin levels post-OGTT, while the MUFA diet showed the most favorable metabolic and blood pressure outcomes.
population_specificity: 41 healthy young males (29 underwent OGTT).
effective_dosage: 38% fat (22% MUFA) in the MUFA diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of monounsaturated fats versus high and low glycemic index carbohydrates on blood glucose and lipid metabolism in NIDDM subjects.
results_summary: The study found that high-mono high-GI diets improved HDL-cholesterol levels compared to high-GI diets, but showed no significant effects on glucose metabolism. No other metabolic differences were observed between the diets.
population_specificity: Variably controlled NIDDM subjects (14 male, 7 female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (diets contained 35% fat as monounsaturated fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-monounsaturated-fat diets versus low-saturated-fat, high-carbohydrate diets on lipoprotein profiles and glycemic control in patients with diabetes.
results_summary: High-monounsaturated-fat diets improved lipoprotein profiles by reducing fasting plasma triacylglycerol and VLDL-cholesterol concentrations by 19% and 22%, respectively, and modestly increasing HDL-cholesterol without adversely affecting LDL-cholesterol. They also enhanced glycemic control and did not induce weight gain when energy intake was controlled.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 or type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a very-low-fat diet versus a low-fat diet supplemented with monounsaturated fat (olive oil) on plasma lipid levels in individuals with hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The low-fat diet with monounsaturated fat resulted in significantly less reduction in HDL cholesterol compared to the very-low-fat diet. Both diets significantly lowered LDL cholesterol and total cholesterol levels from baseline.
population_specificity: Twenty-four free-living subjects with hypercholesterolemia.
effective_dosage: Low-fat diet (26% of energy from fat) supplemented with olive oil and olive oil-based margarine.
study_duration: Two 3-week intervention periods following a 2-week baseline diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of incorporating high-oleic sunflower oil (HOSO) into swine diets on the fatty acid composition and sensory properties of pork products.
results_summary: The study found that pork products from HOSO-fed swine had significantly lower saturated fatty acids, higher monounsaturated fatty acids, and improved monounsaturated-to-saturated fatty acid ratios, with no adverse effects on cooking loss or most sensory attributes.
population_specificity: Swine (pigs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing monounsaturated fat content in pork through dietary modifications (using rapeseed and canola oil) could produce a healthier meat product without compromising quality.
results_summary: The study found that monounsaturated fatty acid content in pork increased significantly with canola oil supplementation, reducing saturated fatty acids and improving the M/S ratio in adipose tissue and muscle, while meat quality traits remained unaffected.
population_specificity: Angus X Hereford steers and pigs.
effective_dosage: 10% or 20% canola oil in the diet for pigs; 20% rapeseed in the diet for cattle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of gut-oriented interventions, including dietary factors like monounsaturated fat, in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study did not provide specific findings on monounsaturated fat but suggested that gut-directed interventions, such as diet modifications, may influence MS pathogenesis by modulating the inflammatory response.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and related inflammatory demyelinating diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a food powder supplement, which increased monounsaturated fat intake, could improve diet composition, reduce inflammation, and lower blood pressure in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that increased monounsaturated fat intake, as part of the food powder supplement, significantly improved inflammatory markers (reduced NF-κB, sICAM-1, hs-CRP, and increased adiponectin) and lowered systolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly (45-75 years) overweight or obese patients with stage one hypertension.
effective_dosage: 100 g of food powder supplement per day (specific monounsaturated fat content not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of nut consumption (a source of monounsaturated fats) on serum fatty acid concentrations and their relationship with glycemic control markers and CHD risk in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Full-dose nut supplementation significantly increased serum oleic acid and MUFAs in the phospholipid fraction, which were inversely associated with CHD risk factors and glycemic control markers.
population_specificity: 117 subjects with type 2 diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-monounsaturated-fat enteral formula versus a high-carbohydrate formula on glycemic and lipid control in hospitalized type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The high-monounsaturated-fat formula (Glucerna) showed neutral effects on glycemic control and lipid metabolism compared to the high-carbohydrate formula (Precitene Diabet), which increased mean glucose levels. Glucerna also had better gastrointestinal tolerance, with fewer instances of diarrhea but more nausea than Precitene.
population_specificity: Hospitalized type 2 diabetic patients with neurologic disorders or head and neck cancer surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Moringa oleifera leaf meal (MOLM) supplementation on growth performance, oxidative stress, behavior, and economic outcomes in early-weaned piglets.
results_summary: MOLM supplementation significantly improved growth performance (9.24% higher final body weight, 17.73% greater weight gain), reduced oxidative stress (lower malondialdehyde levels), decreased stress-related behaviors (e.g., belly nosing), and increased economic profitability.
population_specificity: Early-weaned Landlly piglets (35 days old, average weight 8.66 ± 0.38 kg).
effective_dosage: 5% MOLM supplementation in the basal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hypoglycemic activity of Moringa dietary fibers (MDFs) with different particle sizes in vitro and in vivo and explore the related mechanisms.
results_summary: MDFs, particularly MDF200 and MDF80, showed significant hypoglycemic effects by improving insulin resistance, reducing oxidative stress, modulating gut microbiota, increasing beneficial SCFAs, and activating key signaling pathways like GPR43/AMPK and PI3K/Akt.
population_specificity: High-fat diet and streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetic mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (particle sizes MDF40, MDF80, MDF200 mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of partially replacing dietary polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) with monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) on fatty acid profiles and rheological properties in heavy pigs.
results_summary: Partial substitution of PUFA with MUFA increased MUFA in intramuscular polar lipids and n-3 fatty acids in intramuscular lipid fractions while decreasing the n-6/n-3 ratio. Dietary vitamin E affected some rheological properties of backfat, but consistency remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Heavy pigs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of oleamide (OLA), a bioactive compound from Moringa oleifera, in mitigating liver fibrosis by modulating the TGF-β/SMAD2/3 signaling pathway.
results_summary: OLA significantly reduced pro-fibrotic effectors in activated LX-2 cells, suppressed key genes and proteins in the TGF-β/SMAD2/3 pathway, and demonstrated high binding affinity to pathway proteins, indicating its potential as a therapeutic agent for liver fibrosis.
population_specificity: LX-2 human hepatic stellate cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) activity of Moringa oleifera protein and its underlying molecular mechanism.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera protein inhibited Jurkat cell proliferation, induced apoptosis and cycle arrest, increased autophagy, and regulated the MAPK/AKT pathway to suppress leukemia cell growth.
population_specificity: Jurkat cells (a human T-cell leukemia cell line) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the coagulation-flocculation potential of aqueous Moringa stenopetala seed extract (MSE) to alum for fecal sludge treatment from a resource recovery perspective.
results_summary: MSE outperformed alum, achieving 94% COD removal, higher calorific value (18.4 MJ/kg), lower sludge volume (259 mL/L), and higher total solid concentration (48.8 g/L) at optimal conditions (216 mg/g TS, pH 2.2).
population_specificity: Fecal sludge treatment (not human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant activity of Moringa oleifera leaf infusion and its protective effects against methotrexate-induced damage in mice.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa leaf infusion exhibited significant antioxidant activity in vitro and reduced methotrexate-induced hematological, biochemical, histological, and genotoxic damage in mice. The infusion also improved liver antioxidant enzyme levels.
population_specificity: Female Swiss albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether steam-treated Moringa leaf powder (SMLP) improves bread expansion, sensory qualities, and yeast viability compared to untreated MLP.
results_summary: SMLP increased specific loaf volume (2.2 to 4.6 cm³/g), improved yeast viability (48% to 72%), retained high antioxidant activity, delayed bread staling, and enhanced sensory attributes like aroma and appearance.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and food product testing)
effective_dosage: 5% substitution level for wheat flour in bread formulations

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the polyphenolic content of Moringa oleifera (MO) aqueous extracts and evaluate their neuroprotective effects, particularly in inhibiting amyloid aggregation linked to Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: MO extracts showed high polyphenol content and strong inhibition of amyloid aggregation. In an AD cell model, MO extract improved cell viability, reduced mitochondrial reactive oxygen species, and decreased Aβ1-42 production.
population_specificity: Retinoic acid-differentiated SH-SY5Y cells (an AD cell model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the contents of Moringa oleifera leaf (ML) and root (MR) extracts and characterize their effects on cell behavior, particularly cell growth, chemotaxis, and development life cycle.
results_summary: The study found that ML extract significantly decreased cell growth and delayed the development life cycle in Dictyostelium discoideum, while MR extract did not show these effects. The high levels of flavonoids and apigenin in ML extract were suggested as potential factors for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Dictyostelium discoideum (a cellular model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera leaf extract (MOLE) could counteract lead acetate-induced testicular toxicity and improve semen quality in rats.
results_summary: MOLE administration improved sperm quality markers (motility, viability, membrane integrity) and reduced oxidative stress in lead-exposed rats, though some parameters (SOD, testosterone, sperm count) did not fully recover at the highest dose (500 mg/kg).
population_specificity: Male rats exposed to lead acetate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Moringa oleifera-mediated gold nanoparticles (Au-NPs) in treating lung cancer, specifically targeting A549 cell lines.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa oleifera-mediated Au-NPs exhibited significant cytotoxic and apoptotic effects on A549 lung cancer cells, with an IC50 value of 50 μg/mL. Both tested concentrations (25 μg/mL and 50 μg/mL) showed substantial anti-cancer properties, as confirmed by DAPI staining.
population_specificity: A549 lung cancer cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and compare the effectiveness of Moringa seed powder and cactus pad powder as natural coagulants for treating textile wastewater.
results_summary: Moringa seed powder reduced turbidity by 82.33% under optimal conditions (pH 4, 5 g/l dose, 40 min mixing time), but cactus pad powder was more effective in reducing turbidity, TDS, and TSS, leading to its recommendation over Moringa.
population_specificity: Textile industry wastewater in Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating raw moringa seed powder (MSP) into slag-based geopolymers improves mechanical strength and adsorption capacity for crystal violet dye removal.
results_summary: The study found that adding MSP (0.2%, 0.6%, and 1% by weight) to slag-based geopolymers enhanced compressive strength (up to 25.8% improvement) and adsorption capacity (up to 322.58 mg/g for crystal violet dye). The SM1 mix (0.2% MSP) showed the highest mechanical strength, while SM3 (1% MSP) exhibited the highest adsorption activity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 0.2%, 0.6%, and 1% MSP by weight in geopolymer mixes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential antibacterial activity of Moringa oleifera ethanolic extract against somatic cell count (SCC) and Staphylococcus aureus count in cows with subclinical mastitis.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera ethanolic extract significantly reduced SCC and S. aureus counts, though its effect was slightly less than that of Selenium nanoparticles and Ciprofloxacin. The extract demonstrated notable antibacterial effects comparable to conventional treatments.
population_specificity: Dairy cows with subclinical mastitis in the Kafrelsheikh governorate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera leaf-derived carbon dots (MoCDs) could regulate reactive oxygen species (ROS) metabolism to preserve postharvest flowering Chinese cabbage.
results_summary: MoCDs demonstrated superior antioxidant activity compared to M. oleifera extract, reducing ROS accumulation by enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity and increasing non-enzymatic antioxidants, thereby delaying leaf senescence and preserving quality.
population_specificity: Postharvest flowering Chinese cabbage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat treatment on the allergenicity and protein properties of Moringa oleifera leaves and simulate its behavior during cooking and digestion.
results_summary: The study found that heat treatment altered the allergenicity and protein characteristics of Moringa leaves, with findings consistent with sensitization experiments. The analysis of fructose 1,6 bisphosphate aldolase (FBA) supported the allergenic activity of the peptide.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Moringa oleifera's potential as a natural intervention for preventing and managing chronic diseases due to its phytochemical composition and pharmacological properties.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa exhibits anti-inflammatory, anti-hyperglycemic, cardioprotective, and anti-obesity effects, with potential benefits for diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, obesity, neurodegenerative disorders, and cancer. However, variability in bioactive compounds and inconsistent clinical outcomes limit its widespread application.
population_specificity: Not specified (general chronic disease context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and mechanisms of Moringa oleifera extract in treating migraine, focusing on its potential to inhibit apoptosis and modulate NMDA receptor activity.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera extract reduced migraine symptoms by inhibiting apoptosis, as evidenced by decreased Caspase-3 and Bax expression, and showed comparable efficacy to sumatriptan in behavioral tests. However, no significant changes were observed in Nr2b or Bcl-2 expression levels.
population_specificity: Rats induced with migraine-like conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether priming rice seeds with moringa leaf extract (MLE) could mitigate salinity-induced stress and improve growth and physiological responses in two rice cultivars.
results_summary: MLE treatment reduced oxidative stress and improved salinity tolerance in both rice cultivars by enhancing antioxidative defenses (enzymatic and non-enzymatic) and mitigating adverse effects on growth, photosynthesis, and biochemical parameters. SG 65 (salt-tolerant line) showed higher responsiveness to MLE than Giza 177 (salt-sensitive cultivar).
population_specificity: Two rice cultivars (Giza 177 and SG 65) under low and high salinity stress conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of co-precipitation and high-pressure treatment on the structural and functional properties of millet-moringa protein co-precipitates.
results_summary: Co-precipitation and high-pressure treatment significantly improved water and oil holding capacity, emulsifying stability, solubility, and in vitro protein digestibility of millet and moringa protein isolates.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial potential of Moringa oleifera essential oil, both individually and in combination with cinnamon and black seed oils, against Staphylococcus aureus.
results_summary: The combination of Moringa, cinnamon, and black seed oils showed significant synergistic antibacterial effects, outperforming individual oils and conventional antibiotics like tetracycline, with minimal cytotoxicity (97.6% viability of human skin fibroblasts). The optimal mixture ratio (1:1:1) drastically reduced MIC values for all three oils.
population_specificity: Staphylococcus aureus MCC 1351 (bacterial strain) and normal human skin fibroblasts (HSF) for cytotoxicity testing.
effective_dosage: Optimal mixture ratio: 0.338 mL moringa, 0.307 mL cinnamon, 0.355 mL black seed oil per mL (v/v).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how submerged fermentation with lactic acid bacteria (LAB) affects the extraction of phenolic compounds from moringa leaves and their subsequent antioxidant activity.
results_summary: Fermentation with specific LAB strains significantly increased phenolic acids and total flavonoids in moringa extracts, with P. acidilactici CECT 98 showing the highest improvement (50.12% increase in flavonoids). The optimized sonotrode extraction method enhanced the yield of health-promoting phytochemicals.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Moringa oleifera leaf extract could protect against cyclophosphamide-induced ovarian damage and reproductive dysfunction in female rats.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with Moringa oleifera leaf extract (250 mg/kg) significantly improved hormonal balance, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and preserved ovarian and uterine structure in rats exposed to cyclophosphamide.
population_specificity: Female Wistar albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Moringa peregrina extract-selenium nanoparticles (MPE-SeNPs) against oxidative damage and inflammation caused by HgCl₂ exposure in mice.
results_summary: MPE-SeNPs demonstrated significant antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, improving lung antioxidant status, downregulating pro-inflammatory genes, and reducing oxidative damage in HgCl₂-exposed mice. The nanoparticles also enhanced plasma lipid profiles and lung tissue repair.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to HgCl₂.
effective_dosage: 1/50 and 1/20 of the LD50 (773 mg/kg), with an effective dose of 38.65 mg/kg body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the nutritional profile and antipyretic activity of Moringa oleifera leaves, bark, and root extracts in different regions of Punjab, Pakistan.
results_summary: The methanolic extract of M. oleifera leaves showed the highest antipyretic activity compared to bark and root extracts, significantly lowering temperature in baker's yeast-induced pyrexia. The S1 leaves exhibited superior proximate composition and antipyretic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal or human study not clearly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with 4% Moringa leaf powder, alone or combined with conductive electronic cooling pads, could mitigate oxidative stress and inflammation in heat-stressed sows and their piglets.
results_summary: Moringa supplementation increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-10 and IL-1ra) in colostrum and influenced oxidative stress markers in sows, but had no significant effect on piglet serum oxidative index or intestinal inflammation. Cooling pads combined with Moringa showed some benefits in reducing oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Late gestation sows and their piglets under heat stress conditions.
study_duration: From late gestation through lactation (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Moringa oleifera L. nanosuspension extract (MONE) on HSP-10 and HSP-70 expressions under orthodontic mechanical force (OMF) in Wistar rats.
results_summary: MONE administration significantly increased HSP-10 expression and decreased HSP-70 expression in alveolar bone under OMF, with peak effects observed at different time points (HSP-70 peaked on day 14, HSP-10 on day 21).
population_specificity: Wistar rats (Rattus norvegicus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera leaf extract (MOLE) could protect C2C12 myoblasts from oxidative stress-induced damage by restoring redox balance and enhancing recovery.
results_summary: MOLE restored glutathione homeostasis, improved total antioxidant capacity, increased cell viability, and promoted faster wound closure in myoblasts exposed to H2O2-induced oxidative stress. The metabolomic analysis identified key bioactive compounds in MOLE, including glucosinolates and flavonoids, which likely contributed to these protective effects.
population_specificity: C2C12 myoblasts (a mouse skeletal muscle cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Moringa oleifera as a natural adsorbent for heavy metal removal in water treatment and its role in reducing carbon footprint.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa oleifera is a simple, effective, and eco-friendly adsorbent for removing heavy metals from contaminated water, with potential applications in both developed and rural communities. The review highlighted its invasive growth tendency and low carbon footprint as advantages.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on environmental application, not human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa ethanol extract could protect against oxidative lung damage induced by sodium valproate in rats.
results_summary: Moringa extract reduced oxidative lung damage caused by sodium valproate, as evidenced by improved biochemical parameters and histopathological findings. The extract demonstrated protective and therapeutic effects against valproate-induced lung damage.
population_specificity: Female Sprague Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 300 mg/kg body weight (Moringa extract), 500 mg/kg body weight (sodium valproate)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the bioactive properties of Moringa stenopetala leaves, including antioxidant activity, mineral content, and anticancer effects.
results_summary: Methanol and ethanol extracts showed high antioxidant activity and growth inhibition of the MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cell line, inducing apoptosis and cell cycle arrest. The ethanolic extract also enhanced cytotoxicity when combined with doxorubicin, and molecular docking predicted inhibitory effects on key proteins.
population_specificity: In vitro (MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cell line)
interactions: Enhanced cytotoxicity when combined with doxorubicin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro anti-leukemia capabilities of Moringa oleifera aqueous and ethanolic leaf extracts, focusing on cytotoxicity and apoptotic pathways in leukemia cells.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa extracts exhibited cytotoxicity, with leukemia cells (Jurkat and Raji) being more sensitive than healthy peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). The extracts increased P21 expression in Jurkat cells and elevated P21, BCL2, and Survivin in Raji cells, while P53 remained unchanged in both.
population_specificity: Leukemia cell lines (Jurkat and Raji) and healthy peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) as controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a simplified, cost-effective method for producing a natural coagulant from Moringa oleifera seeds to improve water treatment in resource-limited areas.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the simplified method produced a coagulant capable of achieving 100% turbidity removal using only 5 mL per liter of water, with production completed in under 30 minutes. The method eliminated the need for complex techniques or chemical additives, making it practical for resource-limited communities.
population_specificity: Vulnerable populations in regions with limited water treatment infrastructure.
effective_dosage: 5 mL of coagulant per liter of water.
study_duration: Not specified (coagulation tests were likely immediate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether feeding Moringa oleifera (4% of the diet) to lactating sows under heat stress could improve their welfare, oxidative damage, and production performance.
results_summary: Moringa increased the fat content in milk but did not significantly affect litter growth or feed intake. The study found no impact of Moringa on sow respiration rate, rectal temperature, or body weight loss compared to the control diet.
population_specificity: Mixed parity Yorkshire × Landrace sows (n = 48) under moderate heat stress conditions.
study_duration: From gestation day 110 to day 21 of lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of Moringa oleifera leaf polysaccharides (MOLPs) on LPS-activated intestinal epithelial cells (IEC6) and the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: MOLP treatment significantly promoted cell migration, increased IL-10 production, reduced apoptosis and pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6), and inhibited inflammatory signaling pathways (TLR-4, MyD88, pIκB-α, NF-κB p65). It also restored tight junction proteins (ZO-1, occludin) disrupted by LPS.
population_specificity: Intestinal epithelial cells (IEC6) in vitro.
effective_dosage: Low (25 µg/mL), medium (50 µg/mL), high (100 µg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge about Moringa oleifera Lam.'s potential in treating diabetes mellitus, focusing on its hypoglycemic effects.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera Lam. significantly decreased fasting glucose levels in rodents after 3 months of consumption, demonstrating notable hypoglycemic effects. The study highlights its potential as a medicinal food for diabetes management.
population_specificity: Rodents (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ethanolic M. oleifera leaves extract could protect against oxidative stress in tongue tissue caused by valproic acid (VPA) and identify bioactive compounds responsible for these effects.
results_summary: M. oleifera extract reduced oxidative damage in tongue tissue, with niazimin-A and niazimin-B showing high binding affinities to MPO and LDH enzymes, suggesting potential protective effects when used with VPA.
population_specificity: Female Sprague Dawley rats aged 3.0-3.5 months (160-250 g).
interactions: Potential interaction with valproic acid (VPA) noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether moringa biscuits combined with snakehead fish could improve the nutritional status of pregnant women with chronic energy deficiency (CED).
results_summary: The study found that moringa biscuits significantly improved the BMI of pregnant women with CED (P 0.000), though no difference was observed in upper arm circumference between groups (P 0.247). The intervention provided higher energy and nutrient contributions compared to the control.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with chronic energy deficiency (CED) in Sigi Regency, Central Sulawesi, Indonesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Moringa oleifera hydroalcoholic bark extract (MOHE) in treating diabetic foot ulcers by assessing its anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, antioxidant, anti-diabetic, and wound-healing properties.
results_summary: MOHE demonstrated strong anti-diabetic, antioxidant, and antibacterial effects, significantly improved fibroblast proliferation and migration, and enhanced wound healing in diabetic rats and Zebrafish, outperforming Calendula cream.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats and Zebrafish (in vivo), McCoy cells (in vitro).
effective_dosage: 0.2 mg/mL (anti-inflammatory effect), other concentrations varied by assay (e.g., IC50 values).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Superhydrophobic sand mulch and engineered biochar on the growth and physiological responses of Moringa oleifera under arid conditions.
results_summary: The study found that SHS, EB, and SHS+EB treatments significantly improved plant growth metrics (height, trunk diameter, leaf area, biomass) and physiological parameters (chlorophyll content, stomatal conductance, transpiration) compared to controls, with notable water savings and nutrient efficiency under reduced irrigation. Metabolomics analysis revealed higher sugar and organic acid accumulation in treated plants, indicating improved stress adaptation.
population_specificity: Moringa oleifera plants grown under greenhouse conditions simulating arid and hyper-arid environments.
effective_dosage: Not specified for human consumption; soil treatments included 1cm-thick SHS mulch and 2% w/w EB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming Moringa leaf-based vegetable soup could increase breast milk production in breastfeeding mothers with stunted toddlers.
results_summary: The study found that consuming Moringa leaf soup significantly increased adequate milk production from 57% to 76% in the treatment group, with statistical significance (p = 0.000), suggesting it may enhance breast milk production and indirectly support stunting prevention.
population_specificity: Breastfeeding mothers of stunted toddlers (0-2 years) at Leggung Health Centre.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Moringa oleifera and probiotics on growth, immunity, and digestive enzyme activity in Nile tilapia.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera (10%) improved feed conversion ratio, upregulated immune-related gene expression, and increased beneficial gut bacteria while reducing pathogenic bacteria. Probiotics (B. amyloliquefaciens) enhanced weight gain and digestive enzyme activity, with synergistic effects observed when combined with Moringa.
population_specificity: Nile tilapia (initial body weight 35.04 ± 0.01 g)
effective_dosage: 10% Moringa oleifera in basal diet, fed twice daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial, antioxidant, cytotoxic, and phytochemical properties of Moringa oleifera leaf extract and evaluate the pharmacokinetics of its major compound, quercetin.
results_summary: The extract showed strong antibacterial activity against standard and foodborne bacterial strains, significant antioxidant potential due to high phenolic and flavonoid content, and safety at low to moderate concentrations. ADMET analysis indicated favorable pharmacokinetic properties for quercetin.
population_specificity: Standard bacterial strains and foodborne bacterial species (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera (MO) could provide neuroprotective effects against oxidative stress in SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells exposed to H2O2.
results_summary: MO water extract reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS), enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, suppressed apoptotic gene expression (BAX and caspase 3), and promoted neuroplasticity by increasing BDNF mRNA and phosphorylated-Akt/CREB protein levels.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Moringa oleifera seed (MOS) in removing microorganisms, pharmaceutical residues, and antibiotic-resistant genes from wastewater.
results_summary: MOS addition significantly reduced bacterial load, fecal coliforms, and E. coli, with high removal efficiencies for antibiotics like ciprofloxacin and doxycycline. It also reduced the copy number of resistance genes but showed limited effectiveness in removing phosphorus and nitrates.
population_specificity: Water samples from a domestic wastewater treatment plant prototype.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Moringa oleifera seed oil extract could serve as an alternative treatment for schistosomiasis by evaluating its antiparasitic, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects.
results_summary: Moringa oleifera seed oil extract significantly reduced egg numbers, granuloma size, and liver histopathology, improved hepatic enzyme activity, increased total protein and albumin, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, and lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines. It showed comparable or complementary effects to praziquantel (PZQ).
population_specificity: 50 mice divided into control, infected, and treatment groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Moringa oleifera's potential neuroprotective effects, focusing on its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and neurotransmitter-modulating properties.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa oleifera's bioactive compounds enhance brain antioxidant defenses, reduce inflammation, and improve neurotransmitter levels, suggesting therapeutic potential for neurodegenerative disorders. The review highlights the need for further clinical trials to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Moringa-albumin (MA) formulation in maintaining complement regulatory proteins (CD55 and CD59) on erythrocytes in diabetic mice.
results_summary: MA formulation, particularly at the D3 dosage (1500 mg/kg Moringa + 200 mg/kg albumin), significantly increased erythrocyte profiles (TER-119) and CD59 expression, while D1 and D3 dosages significantly elevated CD55 expression compared to untreated diabetic mice.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice.
effective_dosage: D1 - 500 mg/kg Moringa + 620 mg/kg albumin; D2 - 1000 mg/kg Moringa + 420 mg/kg albumin; D3 - 1500 mg/kg Moringa + 200 mg/kg albumin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of WSMoL on reducing anxiety and depressive-like symptoms in a mouse model of unpredictable chronic mild stress (UCMS).
results_summary: WSMoL significantly reversed anxiety and depression-like behaviors induced by UCMS, reduced neuroinflammation (lowered IL-2, IL-6, and TNF-α levels), and increased brain monoamines (dopamine, serotonin, noradrenaline). However, it did not normalize corticosterone secretion.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to UCMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Moringa oleifera's phytochemical profile, therapeutic properties, and potential applications in nutrition, medicine, and public health.
results_summary: The study highlights Moringa's rich bioactive compounds and its potential therapeutic effects, including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and anticancer properties. It also discusses its applications in functional foods and drug development.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Moringa-based homesteads in contributing to Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) such as poverty reduction, food security, health, gender equality, and economic growth.
results_summary: The study found that Moringa-based homesteads improved household income, access to food and medicinal resources, gender equality in farming activities, and climate-smart practices. Adopters reported higher plant diversity and income opportunities compared to non-adopters.
population_specificity: 135 farmers (40 Moringa-based adopters and 60 non-adopters) in Sylhet, Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera seed extract (WEMoS) or its lectin (WSMoL) could prevent oxidative stress and renal injury in pregnant rats exposed to LPS, and subsequent hypertension in their offspring.
results_summary: WEMoS and WSMoL prevented LPS-induced oxidative stress in maternal-placenta-fetal environments, reduced superoxide anion production, and inhibited NADPH oxidase activity. These treatments also prevented hypertension and renal oxidative stress in adult offspring.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera hydroalcoholic leaf extract could mitigate oxidative damage in rat extraorbital lacrimal glands (ELG) induced by sodium valproate (SV).
results_summary: Moringa extract significantly increased antioxidant markers (SOD, CAT, TAS) and reduced oxidative stress markers (LPO, NO, TOS) in rats treated with SV, demonstrating protective effects against SV-induced damage. Protein band density reductions caused by SV were also reversed by Moringa treatment.
population_specificity: Rats with SV-induced ELG dysfunction

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effect of aqueous Moringa oleifera Lam. leaf extract (AMOLE) against cadmium (Cd)-induced hepatotoxicity in human HepG2 hepatocytes.
results_summary: Pretreatment with AMOLE significantly inhibited Cd-induced oxidative stress in HepG2 cells, likely through antioxidant activity, upregulation of antioxidant defenses, and reduction of intracellular Cd accumulation. Metabolomic analysis identified phenolic and carboxylic acids as major constituents, with flavonoids like quercetin contributing to AMOLE's antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Human HepG2 hepatocytes (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Moringa oleifera hydro-alcoholic leaf extracts could protect against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.
results_summary: Moringa extracts significantly reduced cardiac troponin I release and IL-6 levels, indicating protection against cardiomyocyte damage and inflammation, while also enhancing antioxidant activity and reducing oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal model based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether replacing alfalfa-based total mixed ration (TMR) with Moringa spp. could improve carcass characteristics and meat quality traits in lambs.
results_summary: Incorporating Moringa spp. into lamb diets significantly reduced intramuscular fat content and improved tenderness, texture properties, and water-holding capacity. The treatment groups also showed a significant decrease in total non-carcass components compared to the control group, with no observed adverse effects.
population_specificity: 60 intact male lambs of the Harri breed, averaging 24 ± 1 kg in weight and approximately 5 months old.
effective_dosage: T2 (40% M. oleifera), T3 (40% M. peregrina), T4 (20% alfalfa-based TMR + 20% M. oleifera), and T5 (20% alfalfa-based TMR + 20% M. peregrina).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-fibrotic effects of Moringa oleifera Lam. (MO) and its derived compound 1-phenyl-2-pentanol (1-PHE) on TGF-β1-stimulated LX-2 human hepatic stellate cells.
results_summary: Treatment with 1-PHE downregulated fibrosis markers (COL1A1, COL4A1, SMAD2/3, MMP2) and reduced MMP-9 secretion, suggesting inhibition of TGF-β1 and Wnt/β-catenin pathways, indicating potential as an anti-liver-fibrosis agent.
population_specificity: LX-2 human hepatic stellate cells (in vitro study).
